item.title: Louvre Director Acknowledges Failure to Protect Stolen Jewels
item.description: Laurence des Cars told a Senate hearing that she had offered to resign as questions swirl over security measures at museum.

item.title: Vance Says He’s Not in Israel to Babysit Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: Vice President JD Vance said recent visits by top American officials were to monitor the cease-fire, but not “in the sense of, you know, you monitor a toddler.”

item.title: Dozens Killed in Bus Crash in Uganda
item.description: The crash involved multiple vehicles and was one of the deadliest road accidents in the East African country in decades.

item.title: Zelensky Says Strike on Kindergarten Shows Putin Isn’t Serious About Talks
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said an assault by Russia, hours after President Trump put off a meeting with President Vladimir Putin, showed more pressure was needed.

item.title: On the Menu in New York: One Repair, Coming Right Up
item.description: The state leads the country in “repair cafes,” which bring neighbors together while keeping all manner of items out of the trash.

item.title: Man Is Shot and Tents Set on Fire Outside Serbia’s Parliament
item.description: A suspect was arrested after a blaze broke out among structures erected by supporters of President Aleksandar Vucic. Protests against his government have rumbled for months.

item.title: Thai Official Resigns Over Allegations of Links to Scam Network
item.description: Thailand’s deputy finance minister, Vorapak Tanyawong, was accused of ties to the Cambodian cybercrime hubs he had been appointed to combat.

item.title: World Falling Short on Methane Pledge, U.N. Report Finds
item.description: Several agency programs are trying to track and reduce methane emissions around the world. To meet global targets, use of them needs to speed up.

item.title: Civilian Massacres Follow Syrian Leaders’ Promises of Peace
item.description: Ten months after rebels toppled the long-entrenched Assad regime, little-checked bloodshed has led many Syrians to abandon hope that the years of brutality may be over.

item.title: Stolen Louvre Jewelry Worth Over $100 Million, Paris Prosecutor Says
item.description: The eight pieces are unlikely to garner that price if they are split apart or melted, the prosecutor said Tuesday.

item.title: Drone Sightings in Europe: What We Know
item.description: Airports in several countries have temporarily closed in recent weeks after reports of drones in the skies. Experts say the response has exposed a lack of preparedness.

item.title: What’s Left to Be Done in the Gaza Cease-Fire Deal
item.description: Israel and Gaza have signed a cease-fire that mediators hope will bring two years of deadly war to an end. The deal is based on the first phase of President Trump’s plan, but Phase 2 remains uncertain. David Halbfinger, our Jerusalem bureau chief, walks us through the four main stumbling blocks ahead.

item.title: As Suspicious Drones Plague Germany, Officials Are Unsure How to Respond
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz said, “We suspect that Russia is behind most of these drone flights” around vital sites like ports and airports.

item.title: In a Reversal, Trump Will Not Meet With Putin in Coming Weeks
item.description: The back-and-forth was the latest example of President Trump teasing a breakthrough, only to be pulled back by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: Deforestation Is Imperiling Coffee Cultivation, Report Finds
item.description: A new report by an industry watchdog adds to growing scientific consensus that as forests are felled to make way for coffee farms, rainfall decreases and crops are more likely to fail.

item.title: A Nepali Town Mourns a Native Son Who Died a Hamas Captive
item.description: The family of Bipin Joshi, a student, had campaigned internationally for his release and had held out hope until the end that after two years in Gaza, he would return alive.

item.title: With Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire, Some Pro-Palestinian Protesters Look Back at Their Movement, Ruefully
item.description: Activists welcome the truce. But the backlash to their demonstrations, some said, offered sobering lessons about power and politics.

item.title: China, Xi and the S-Word
item.description: The Chinese president has been in office for more than a decade, but Xi Jinping’s succession is a touchy subject.

item.title: Around Here, It’s Not a Party Without a Bone-Rattling Speaker Truck
item.description: A towering wall of speakers on wheels, shaking everything in sight: In many Javanese villages, there’s no big celebration without one.

item.title: Neo-Nazi Case in UK Highlights Threat From Extreme-Right Wing Terrorism
item.description: Three men in northern England were sentenced last week for preparing acts of terrorism. Their case highlights a growing threat from right-wing extremism, experts said.

item.title: Vance Lands in Israel as U.S. Tries to Shore Up Gaza Cease-Fire Deal
item.description: Vice President JD Vance appeared undeterred by recent flare-ups of violence in Gaza, and he declined to set a deadline for when Hamas must disarm.

item.title: Nations Hesitate to Send Troops to Gaza, Fearing Clashes With Hamas
item.description: The Trump peace plan calls for an international security force in the Gaza Strip, but countries that might send troops are wary of danger, an unclear mission and being seen as occupiers.

item.title: Roundabouts in Keene Help Cut Emissions and Air Pollution
item.description: Despite its small stature, the city of Keene, has become an example of the safety and climate benefits of swapping traffic lights for roundabouts.

item.title: Helping to Save the Bees With Plants in Kansas
item.description: About 97 percent of the land in the state is privately owned. Meet the people helping to make it friendlier for native bugs.

item.title: Reviving California’s Kelp Forests, One Dive at a Time
item.description: Cove by cove, scientists, divers and volunteers are hauling up urchins to protect kelp.

item.title: G.M. to Stop Making Electric Vans in Canada Amid Trump Tariffs
item.description: The announcement, which will eliminate about 1,200 jobs, came less than a week after the carmaker Stellantis said it would move production of a new vehicle to Illinois from a Toronto suburb.

item.title: Louvre Robbery Raises Questions About Security
item.description: Investigators were looking into the alarm systems at an institution that one expert said “wasn’t built with an obsession over security.”

item.title: Latest Trump-Zelensky Meeting Yields No Progress Toward a Cease-fire in Ukraine
item.description: A contentious meeting between President Trump and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine produced no obvious progress toward a cease-fire.

item.title: Eight Shows to See While Art Basel Paris is On
item.description: An array of paintings, as well as textiles, films and handblown glass, will be on display across the French capital this month, while Art Basel Paris is on.

item.title: Cartier, Vuitton and Pinault Use Private Money for Public Art Shows
item.description: In Paris, the Cartier and Vuitton foundations and the Pinault Collection are all presenting major exhibitions running at the same time as Art Basel.

item.title: France Sends Former President Nicolas Sarkozy to Prison to Start 5-Year Sentence
item.description: Nicolas Sarkozy, the president of France from 2007 to 2012, received a five-year sentence after being convicted in a campaign finance scandal.

item.title: With Diwali Comes the Start of Air Pollution Season in New Delhi
item.description: The air quality in India’s capital ranks among the worst in the world, but experts say politics stand in the way of improving it.

item.title: The Louvre Heist
item.description: Today, we look at how thieves pulled off this weekend’s brazen daylight robbery in Paris and why they did it.

item.title: Haiti’s Last President was Killed in 2021. Why Is His Case Taking So Long
item.description: Dozens of people were accused of participating in the assassination of Jovenel Moise, the Haitian president. The two trials involving his killing are flailing.

item.title: Suspect Charged in Paris Museum Heist (No, Not That One)
item.description: A woman from China was charged with stealing gold last month from National Museum of Natural History. It’s one of several high-profile recent thefts from French institutions.

item.title: White House Works to Preserve Gaza Deal Amid Concerns About Netanyahu
item.description: The Trump administration strategy is to try to keep Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel from resuming an all-out assault against Hamas, U.S. officials said.

item.title: Gaza Humanitarian Foundation Operations Unravel
item.description: The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation has suspended its aid operations because of the cease-fire, but it is also running low on funds and faces logistical obstacles to resuming its work.

item.title: Can a U.S.-Australia Deal on Rare Earths Counter China’s Dominance?
item.description: Australia’s got reserves and mining expertise, and the United States is eager to invest in alternatives to China. But building mines, refineries and factories could take years.

item.title: Russia Pushes a State-Controlled ‘Super App’ by Sabotaging Its Rivals
item.description: As the Kremlin throttles WhatsApp and Telegram, the new MAX messaging app is moving Russia closer to a restricted internet without foreign technology.

item.title: ‘Pirate Lizards’ Can Get Around on 3 Legs
item.description: Researchers found more than a hundred lizards of nearly 60 species that survived losing a limb, with some even seeming to thrive.

item.title: From Industry to E.P.A.: Lobbyist Now Oversees Pesticide Rules
item.description: Kyle Kunkler fought for a restricted weed killer that can harm plants and wildlife when it drifts to nearby land. He’s now at the E.P.A., which wants to allow its use.

item.title: Sanae Takaichi is Japan’s New Prime Minister, and She’s a Heavy Metal Drummer
item.description: Sanae Takaichi, a fan of Iron Maiden, had an improbable rise to power. Like her mentor, Shinzo Abe, she is expected to lead Japan to the right.

item.title: Deadly Tornado Hits Suburbs of Paris
item.description: A rare tornado near Paris blew through several towns north of the capital of France, toppling cranes and killing one person.

item.title: How the Louvre Thieves Did It
item.description: My colleagues explain how the brazen daytime jewel heist at the Louvre happened and why.

item.title: Iranian Wedding Video Plunges Top Official Into Scandal
item.description: Rear Adm. Ali Shamkhani oversaw a brutal crackdown on women, but traditional notions of Islamic morality were little on display at his daughter’s wedding.

item.title: Cable Used in Deadly Funicular Crash in Lisbon Not Cleared for Public Transport
item.description: A preliminary report on the accident, which killed 16, said an incorrect cable was being used for the funicular, but that it was not yet possible to know how that figured in the crash.

item.title: To Counter China’s Hold on Rare Minerals, Trump Turns to Australia
item.description: The United States hopes to become less dependent on China by increasing access to mineral-rich countries. Rare earth metals are vital to an array of modern industries.

item.title: A Chinese Woman Builds a New Career in a Man’s World
item.description: An all-female repair business is challenging gender norms in China and catering to a growing population of single women seeking safety and comfort at home. We spoke to Ray Hou, who quit her office job to become a professional handywoman, about what motivated her to start a new career.

item.title: The Chinese Influencer Who Made a Career of Lying Flat
item.description: For many young Chinese, the relentless pressure to succeed has given way to a new minimalist lifestyle known as lying flat. We followed Tom Jia, a popular influencer who left his demanding job in Shenzhen to travel across China in search of the country’s most affordable — and least stressful — places to live.

item.title: In China’s Crowded Hospitals, She Found a New Career
item.description: As China’s population grows older, a new industry of gig workers is stepping in to help older patients navigate a complex, bureaucratic hospital system. We spent time with Jessica Wang, a 49-year-old mother from Beijing who found steady income and a renewed sense of purpose by becoming a professional hospital companion.
